facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 251 of 1954 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 251 of 1954.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated April 22, 1952, of Punjab High Court in Civil Regular First Appeal No. 1/E of 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated April 22, 1952, of the Punjab High Court in Civil Regular First Appeal No. 1/E of 1947

facts.text: Arising out of judgment and decree dated July 1, 1947, of SubJudge Ambala in Suit No. 239 of 1946.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and decree dated July 1, 1947, of the Court of SubJudge, Ambala in Suit No. 239 of 1946.

facts.text: Punjab High Court reversed decree of Subordinate Judge Ambala dated July 1, 1947, dismissing Suit No. 239 of 1946 on April 22, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: by a Division Bench of the Punjab High Court reversing the decree passed on July 1, 1947, by the First Class Subordinate Judge, Ambala in favour of the plaintiff and dismissing the plaintiffs Suit No. 239 of 1946.

facts.text: Certificate granted by Division Bench on December 19, 1952 for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal has been preferred on the strength of a certificate granted by the Division Bench on December 19, 1952.

facts.text: Lala Beni Pershad died in 1910 leaving widow Mst. Daropadi (respondent No. 2) and sons Gokul Chand (respondent No. 1) and Raghunath Das (plaintiff appellant, minor).

anchor.surface_text: One Lala Beni Pershad died in the year 1910 leaving him surviving his widow Mst. Daropadi  defendant respondent No. 2  and two sons by her, namely, Gokul Chand  defendant respondent No. 1  and Raghunath Das  plaintiff appellant  who was then a minor.

facts.text: Lala Beni Pershad left considerable movable properties including G.P. Notes and immovable properties including agricultural land, gardens and houses.

anchor.surface_text: Lala Beni Pershad left companysiderable moveable properties including many G. P. Notes and also various immoveable properties including agricul- tural land, gardens and houses.

facts.text: Family continued joint until disputes arose between brothers in 1934.

anchor.surface_text: After his death the family companytinued to be joint until disputes and. differences arose between the two brothers in 1934.

facts.text: On November 12, 1934, two brothers executed agreement referring partition disputes to arbitration of Lala Ramji Das.

anchor.surface_text: Eventually oil November 12, 1934, the two brothers executed an agreement referring their disputes relating to the partition of the family properties to the arbitration of Lala Ramji Das

facts.text: Gokul Chand held G.P. Notes of value Rs. 26,500 as Karta at date of arbitration reference (alleged he disposed part).

anchor.surface_text: who was a companymon relation. It is alleged that the respondent Gokul Chand had disposed of part of the   F. P. Notes and that at the date of the reference to arbitration G. P. Notes of the value of Rs. 26,500 only were held by Gokul Chand, as the Karta of the family.

facts.text: Arbitrator made award on June 21, 1936, signed by both brothers.

anchor.surface_text: On June 21, 1936, the arbitrator made an award which was signed by both the, brothers statedly ill token of their acceptance thereof.

facts.text: Award registered on July 28, 1936.

anchor.surface_text: The award was registered on July 28, 1936.

facts.text: Award directed G.P. Notes Rs. 13,300 to Gokul Chand and Mst. Daropadi, Rs. 13,200 to Raghunath Das and Mst. Daropadi; interest to Daropadi till death.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the P. Notes the arbitrator directed and awarded that out of the G. P. Notes of the value of Rs. 26,500, which then stood in the name of Gokul Chand, G. P. Notes of the value of Rs. 13,300 should be entered into the names of Gokul Chand and Mst. Daropadi and the remaining Notes of the value of Rs. 13,200 should be endorsed in the names of Raghunatb Das and Mst. Daropadi and that till her death Mst. Daropadi should alone be entitled to the interest on the entire G. P. Notes of the value of Its. 26,500

facts.text: Arbitrator directed Gokul Chand to pay Raghunath Das Rs. 20,000 in four installments with interest.

anchor.surface_text: The arbitrator further directed Gokul Chand to pay to Raghunath Das a sum of Rs. 20,000 in four several instalments together with interest thereon as mentioned therein.

facts.text: On August 31, 1936, Gokul Chand applied to District Judge Ambala to file award under Sch II para 20 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: On August 31, 1936, Gokul Chand applied to the District Judge, Ambala under paragraph 20, of Schedule 11 to the Code of Civil Procedure for filing the award.

facts.text: On November 18, 1936, District Judge filed modified award and passed decree.

anchor.surface_text: By an order made on November 18, 1936, the District Judge directed the award as modified by the companypromise to be filed and passed a decree in accordance with the terms of the award thus modified.

facts.text: Raghunath Das applied for execution of decree on November 15, 1939.

anchor.surface_text: On November 15, 1939, Raghunath Das made an application to the companyrt of the District judge for execution of the decree.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge dismissed execution on December 23, 1942, accepting Gokul Chand's jurisdiction objection.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge on December 23, 1942, accepted Gokul Chands plea and dismissed the execution application.

facts.text: High Court Single Judge accepted appeal on April 5, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by Raghunath Das to the High Court a learned Single Judge on April 5, 1944, accepted the appeal,

facts.text: Division Bench reversed Single Judge on March 15, 1945, restoring dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: but on Letters Patent Appeal filed by Gokul Chand the Division Bench on March 15, 1945, reversed the order of the Single Judge and restored the order of dismissal passed by the Subordinate Judge.

facts.text: Raghunath Das instituted Suit No. 80 of 1945 on August 21, 1945 for Rs. 7,310-11-3 balance of Rs.20,000.

anchor.surface_text: Raghunath Das, on August 21, 1945, instituted Suit No. 80 of 1945 against Gokul Chand for the recovery of Rs. 7,310-11-3 being the balance with interest remaining due to him out of the said sum of Rs. 20,000, awarded in his favour.

facts.text: Senior Subordinate Judge decreed Suit 80/1945 on December 22, 1945; no appeal, final.

anchor.surface_text: Gokul Chand raised a number of pleas but eventually all his pleas were negatived and the senior Subordinate Judge, Ambala, by his judgment pronounced on December 22, 1945, decreed the suit in favour of Raghunath Das. Gokul Chand did number file any appeal therefrom and companysequently that decree became final and binding

facts.text: Raghunath Das filed Suit No. 239 of 1946 on June 5, 1946 for transfer of G.P. Notes Rs.13,200 or payment.

anchor.surface_text: On June 5, 1946, Raghunath Das filed in the companyrt of the Senior Subordinate Judge, Ambala a suit being Suit No. 239 of 1946 out of which the present appeal has arisen. In this suit Raghunath Das claimed that Gokul Chand be ordered to transfer G. P. Notes of the value of Rs. 13,200

facts.text: Subordinate Judge decreed Suit 239/1946 in favor of plaintiff on July 1, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Subordinate Judge accordingly decreed the suit in favour of Raghunath Das.

facts.text: Punjab High Court Division Bench dismissed suit as barred by limitation under Art.49 on April 22, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court did number discuss the other issue founded on 0. 2, r. 2, of the Code of Civil Procedure but allowed the appeal and dismissed the suit as barred by limitation.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on May 1, 1958 by DAS J.

arguments.claim: Art. 49 of the Indian Limitation Act had no application to the facts of this case and the suit was governed by the residuary Art. 120

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel appearing for Gokul Chand urged that the suit was one for the recovery of -other specific moveable property that is to say specific moveable property other than those falling within Arta. 48, 48A and 48B of the Indian Limitation Act

arguments.court_reasoning: Suit is for partition and allotment of share from joint movable property, not for specific movable property in specie

anchor.surface_text: under s. 14 of the Indian Limitation Act in computing the period of limitation under Art. 120. The learned Subordinate Judge also held that the cause of action

arguments.court_reasoning: Execution proceedings were civil proceedings prosecuted with due diligence and good faith on same cause of action in court unable to entertain due to jurisdiction defect

arguments.claim: The suit is not barred by Order 2, Rule 2 CPC as cause of action in earlier suit (Suit 80/1945 for Rs.20,000 balance) different from present suit

anchor.surface_text: The learned Subordinate Judge also held that the cause of action in the earlier suit for the recovery of the sum of Rs. 7,310-11-3 was not the same as the cause of action in the present suit

arguments.claim: The suit is one for recovery of other specific movable property governed by Art. 49 Limitation Act (3 years limitation)

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel appearing for Gokul Chand urged that the suit was one for the recovery of -other specific moveable property that is to say specific moveable property other than those falling within Arts. 48, 48A and 48B of the Indian Limitation Act and was accordingly governed by Art. 49.

arguments.court_reasoning: Not suit for specific movable property but for partition/division of joint family G.P. Notes where no specific notes allotted until actual division

arguments.claim: Suit is for specific Government Promissory Notes as per para 18 of plaint specifying numbers, value, year, interest; governed by Art.49; barred by limitation even excluding execution period

anchor.surface_text: In the opinion of the High Court the suit was for the recovery of specific Government promissory notes and this, according to the High Court, was plain from the perusal of para. 18 of the plaint which set out the reliefs claimed by the plaintiff in the suit.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: first instance or in a Court of appeal, against the defendant, shall be excluded where the proceeding is founded upon the same cause of action and is

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court overlooked that award/decree only declared rights, did not specify particular notes; suit is for court-directed division and allotment

arguments.claim: Section 14 Limitation Act has no application to exclude time spent in execution proceedings
arguments.court_reasoning: Execution was civil proceeding with due diligence/good faith on same cause of action; court lacked jurisdiction due to nullity of decree from jurisdictional defect

arguments.claim: Suit not governed by Art.49 as it is for partition/division of joint coparcenary/tenancy-in-common movable property; governed by residuary Art.120 (6 years)
Brothers entitled as joint coparceners then tenants-in-common; no wrongful taking/detention until actual partition; Art.49 terminus a quo inapplicable
Distinguishable from Gopal Chandra Bose v. Surendra Nath Dutt as there defendant had no right/interest in notes
Suit like heir against heirs for share of movable estate governed by Art.120 not 49 (citing Mohomed Riasat Ali v. Mussumat Hasin Banu)
arguments.court_reasoning: Substance is for separating share out of estate and allotment; decree declaring rights does not alter principle

arguments.claim: Execution proceedings qualify under S.14 Lim Act: civil proceedings, due diligence/good faith, same cause of action (enforce rights under decree), prosecuted in court unable to entertain due to jurisdiction defect
Execution court lacked jurisdiction because decree nullity (passed without jurisdiction re agricultural land partition); defect attaches to decree

holdings.text: The suit is not one for recovery of other specific movable property under Art. 49 of the Limitation Act but is a suit for partition and division of movable properties held jointly or as tenants-in-common governed by the residuary Art. 120.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Award/decree declared rights without specifying particular notes; brothers held as coparceners/tenants-in-common until actual division; no wrongful taking/detention; distinguishes Gopal Chandra Bose; follows Mohomed Riasat Ali.

holdings.text: Raghunath Das is entitled to exclude under S.14 of the Limitation Act the time spent prosecuting the execution proceedings from November 15, 1939 to March 15, 1945.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Execution was civil proceeding prosecuted with due diligence and good faith on same cause of action (enforce decree rights); court unable to entertain due to jurisdictional defect in original decree making it a nullity attached to execution.

holdings.text: The suit is within the period of limitation prescribed by Art. 120.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Governed by 6-year Art.120 from accrual; excludes execution period under S.14; filed well within time.

holdings.text: A decree passed without jurisdiction is a nullity and the defect attaches to the decree preventing the executing court from entertaining the execution.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdictional defect in court passing decree (partition of agricultural land) renders decree nullity; propagates to executing court lacking jurisdiction.

holdings.text: The execution proceedings and the present suit are founded on the same cause of action of enforcing rights declared under the decree upon the award.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Both seek to enforce same rights to G.P. Notes share under decree; difference only in procedure (execution vs. suit).

holdings.text: The appeal is allowed, judgment and decree of the High Court set aside, and case remanded to High Court for decision on issue of whether suit barred by O.2 R.2 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: The result, therefore, is that we accept the appeal, set aside the judgment and decree of the High Court and remand the case back to the High Court for a decision on issue No.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court did not decide O.2 R.2 issue as limitation sufficed; now limitation resolved in favor of plaintiff, requires determination.

R. 20 I. A. 155. anxious to have his share of the G. P. Notes separately allocated to him.

precedents.cited_proposition: a suit by an heir against other heirs to recover his share of the moveable estate of a deceased person is not one for specific moveable property wrongfully taken such as is contemplated by Art 49, but is governed by Art. 120
